channel.title: [Pi] Interface [Server Sided]
channel.description: Hey guys, so I made a new timer interface that says Remaining Time:, but I'm not sure how to make it say Remaining Time: 5 seconds and then it counts down. How would I make it so that the actual timer is displayed right next to my interface?

item.title: [Pi] Interface [Server Sided]
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:27, topic:524717”]i dont understand this line, could you explain it please?

the operator is called the ternary operator (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%3F:) it’s basically a simplified if-else conditional
in this case it is saying

if minutes are greater than 1, we will return the minutes, otherwise, return seconds.

it’s easier than doing something more verbose like this:

if (minutes > 1) { return minutes; } else { return seconds; }

Read full topic

item.title: [Pi] Interface [Server Sided]
item.dc:creator: @b00mz1029 b00mz1029
item.description:
@b00mz1029 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:25, topic:524717”]would you guys stop loveingoff and actually try and help this fellow

@op, okay, you have the interface down, great! now sending to the interface should be the easy part, I would do something along the lines of this:

	/**
	 * Returns the current time, in minutes or seconds.
	 * @param initialTime	The initial time, in seconds.
	 * @return	If there is more than one minute, return minutes, otherwise return seconds.
	 */
	public static int minutesToSeconds(int initialTime) {
		int minutes = (int) Math.floor(initialTime / 60);
		int seconds = initialTime - (minutes * 60);
		return minutes > 1 ? minutes : seconds;
	}

(I just wrote this code, it will work in theory, I have not tested it.)

and now I’m sure you’re wondering Mr. AtomicInt_ now that you gave me that, I still don’t know how to draw it to my interface. Well, I am getting there.

there is a frame (frame 126, to be specific) which allows you to write a string to an interface, assuming you’re using PI, I would again do something along the lines of:

int time = minutesToSeconds(180); // three minutes
client.getPA().sendFrame126("Time remaining: " + time, string_id);

you can figure out how to format the time yourself.[/quote]
Oh my lord thank you so much for your help bro!!

Read full topic

item.title: [Pi] Interface [Server Sided]
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

would you guys stop fuckingoff and actually try and help this fellow

@op, okay, you have the interface down, great! now sending to the interface should be the easy part, I would do something along the lines of this:

	/**
	 * Returns the current time, in minutes or seconds.
	 * @param initialTime	The initial time, in seconds.
	 * @return	If there is more than one minute, return minutes, otherwise return seconds.
	 */
	public static int minutesToSeconds(int initialTime) {
		int minutes = (int) Math.floor(initialTime / 60);
		int seconds = initialTime - (minutes * 60);
		return minutes > 1 ? minutes : seconds;
	}

(I just wrote this code, it will work in theory, I have not tested it.)

and now I’m sure you’re wondering Mr. AtomicInt_ now that you gave me that, I still don’t know how to draw it to my interface. Well, I am getting there.

there is a frame (frame 126, to be specific) which allows you to write a string to an interface, assuming you’re using PI, I would again do something along the lines of:

int time = minutesToSeconds(180); // three minutes
client.getPA().sendFrame126("Time remaining: " + time, string_id);

you can figure out how to format the time yourself.

Read full topic
